items.title: Joshua Tree National Park
items.summary: Hidden out in the desert near Palm Springs, Joshua Tree is an experience unlike many other. Defined by its rocky structures and namesake trees, this park presents the unique experience of a desert at high elevation. With very few mapped hikes and landmarks, this park…
items.content_html: Hidden out in the desert near Palm Springs, Joshua Tree is an experience unlike many other. Defined by its rocky structures and namesake trees, this park presents the unique experience of a desert at high elevation. With very few mapped hikes and landmarks, this park is perfect for those exploring on their own.

items.title: Yosemite National Park
items.summary: Set back in central California far to the east of San Francisco, Yosemite National Park is a favorite destination of adventurers of all kinds. With massive granite peaks and tree-filled valleys, this park offers fun of all varieties. Flowing waterfalls serve to accent the majesty…
items.content_html: Set back in central California far to the east of San Francisco, Yosemite National Park is a favorite destination of adventurers of all kinds. With massive granite peaks and tree-filled valleys, this park offers fun of all varieties. Flowing waterfalls serve to accent the majesty of this park, especially in the winter and spring.

items.title: About the Author
items.summary: Ryan Orlando is a fourth year political science student at UCLA, with a concentration in American politics and minors in digital humanities and public affairs. He is a national park annual passholder and thouroghly enjoys exploring any park he can get to. Through this site,…
items.content_html: Ryan Orlando is a fourth year political science student at UCLA, with a concentration in American politics and minors in digital humanities and public affairs. He is a national park annual passholder and thouroghly enjoys exploring any park he can get to. Through this site, he hopes to educate on the history and importance of our national parks system, as well as raise awareness of the challenges that our parks face. In his free time, Ryan enjoys watching and playing sports, and hanging out with his family, friends, and dog, Kona.

items.title: Zion National Park
items.summary: Located in Southern Utah, about 3 hours from Las Vegas, the majestic Zion Canyon is on of the most popular national parks in the country. With soaring rock formations and awe-insipring views, this park is particularly radiant at sunrise and sunset. Sunset over the Canyon…
items.content_html: Located in Southern Utah, about 3 hours from Las Vegas, the majestic Zion Canyon is on of the most popular national parks in the country. With soaring rock formations and awe-insipring views, this park is particularly radiant at sunrise and sunset.

items.title: Welcome to America's National Parks
items.summary: In 1872, Congress created the first national park: Yellowstone National Park. 44 years later, President Woodrow Wilson established the National Parks Service on August 25, 1916. These two events launched one of the most ambtious and beneficial projects in our nation's history. The National Parks…
items.content_html:
In 1872, Congress created the first national park: Yellowstone National Park. 44 years later, President Woodrow Wilson established the National Parks Service on August 25, 1916. These two events launched one of the most ambtious and beneficial projects in our nation's history. The National Parks system represents some of the best parts of our country, preserving our natural beauty for everyone to enjoy. 

However, this system is not perfect. The national parks are often held on stolen land, taken from indigenous peoples who were never fairly compensated, in a situation where no compensation could ever validate the theft of a home. National parks are also disproportionately enjoyed by white Americans, and undervisited among communities of color. Lost in the beauty of these parks and the overall positivity of this system are these issues and many others.

This website aims to tell two stories: the history of the National Parks system and the story of the opposite perspective, in which the benefit of the parks in not felt in nearly the same way. As the author, I have chosen to focus on a select few parks on the west coast that I have visited, and each page will attempt to tell both stories, along with images that I have captured there.
